docs.lead_paragraph: A woman was found guilty of capital murder today in the shooting death of a pregnant teen-ager whose full-term fetus was cut from her womb. Felecia Scott, 31, could receive the death penalty or life in prison without parole when she is sentenced for the Jan. 31, 1996 slaying of 17-year-old Carethia Curry.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Guilty Verdict in Killing Of Pregnant Teen-Ager

docs.abstract: Felecia Scott is convicted in Tuscaloosa, Ala, of capital murder in shooting death of Carethia Curry, 17, whose full-term baby was cut from her womb, (S)
docs.snippet: A woman was found guilty of capital murder today in the shooting death of a pregnant teen-ager whose full-term fetus was cut from her womb.     Felecia Scott, 31, could receive the death penalty or life in prison without parole when she is sentenced...

docs.lead_paragraph: Reflecting a growing frustration and fear about AIDS, legislators around the country are passing an increasing number of laws intended to protect the public. This latest wave of legislation shifts the focus from earlier laws that protected the civil liberties of H.I.V.-infected people to laws that seek to identify certain people with the virus, notify partners and in some cases punish those who intentionally place others at risk of contracting the virus. At least 29 states now make it a crime to transmit or expose others knowingly to H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, with a third of those states enacting laws in the last two years. This year alone, 16 state legislatures, including New York's, introduced such bills.

headline.main: Wave of Laws Aimed at People With H.I.V.

docs.abstract: Legislators around country, reflecting a growing frustration and fear about AIDS, are passing increasing number of laws to protect public; this latest wave of legislation shifts focus from earlier laws that protected civil liberties of HIV-infected people to laws that seek to identify certain people with virus, notify partners and in some cases punish those who intentionally place others at risk of contracting virus; at least 29 states now make it a crime to transmit ot expose others knowingly to HIV; increasingly, states are mandating HIV testing for specific segments of population, mainly prisoners and pregnant women (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Elective Caesarean section to avoid the pain of labor (Science Times, Sept. 22)? I have given birth naturally three times (no episiotomy) and had major abdominal surgery once. After the births I was perhaps a bit tired, yet I had little pain. I was able to take care of my children immediately.
docs.abstract: Donna Sarapata letter says Caesarean sections have longer recovery period and cause more pain in long run than natural births (Sept 22 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The women who choose elective Caesarean sections to avoid the pain of labor seem to be unaware of the intense post-operative pain of a Caesarean (Science Times, Sept. 22). While the women who deliver vaginally are quickly sitting up and cuddling or nursing their babies, the Caesarean mothers are lying in bed on narcotic painkillers, unable to walk or lift and thus unable to take care of their babies.
docs.abstract: Vicki Madden and Louise Moed letter says women who choose elective Caesarean sections to avoid the pain of labor seem to be unaware of the intense post-operative pain of a Caesarean (Sept 22 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You report (Science Times, Sept. 22) that some English doctors are agreeing to do elective Caesarean sections to avoid malpractice lawsuits in the event that something goes wrong in a vaginal birth. A Caesarean section is not only more expensive, but it is also not natural. (Evolution would have gone in another direction if vaginal delivery were not superior.)
docs.abstract: Katherine Stoecklin letter says it is acceptable for women to have elective Caesarean sections that have no medical justification as long as insurance companies do not have to pay for them (Sept 22 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Manhattan woman was in the first trimester of pregnancy with her first child when she decided how she wanted the baby delivered. She had read about childbirth in pregnancy books, heard war stories from friends and relatives and feared that she could not endure whatever labor pain she might have before the epidural kicked in. She told her doctor that when her pregnancy was full term, she wanted a Caesarean section. ''I spent a long time counseling her,'' said Dr. Andrei Rebarber, her obstetrician at New York University Medical Center. He told her that she had a greater chance for complications, including hemorrhage, infection and death, from a Caesarean section than from vaginal delivery. ''I told her I won't do a Caesarean section without a medical indication. I feel that it's unethical.''

headline.main: Doctors Report Rise in Elective Caesareans

docs.abstract: Some doctors say more women are asking for Caesarean sections, even when they are not necessary; doctors are sharply divided on how to respond; turnaround is being driven by several recent reports that question safety of vaginal deliveries in certain circumstances; British Medical Journal cites as other reasons medical avances like local anesthesia that have made Caesarean sections safer, and evidence that long, difficult vaginal deliveries can cause stress incontinence and other pelvic damage to mother, and cerebral palsy or even death to baby; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the first babies were born to crack addicts in the mid-1980's, images of trembling infants with tubes up their noses led to fears that such children were irreversibly damaged and doomed to grow into violent misfits. The dire predictions failed to materialize by the early 1990's, prompting a different conclusion: that cocaine causes no lingering effects on children born to drug-addicted mothers. Instead, it was asserted, whatever problems the children had could be attributed to poverty and other environmental factors.

headline.main: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak

docs.abstract: Pediatricians and other specialists who work with babies born to crack addicts say that early intervention can fight drug's effect on child; various studies of cocaine-addicted babies throughout country have resulted in contradictory findings; several experts discuss problems with such studies, particularly in regard to factors like environment, mother's life-style and poverty; photo (M)
